awd_titl_txt: LTREB RENEWAL:  Reconciling Innovation and Adaptation During Ongoing Range Expansion
awd_abstract_narration:
In plants and animals, past and present forms and functions are linked across time and space. This fundamental principle underlies the continuity of life on Earth. It also shapes contemporary adaptations. Yet, despite the importance of this principle, scientists know little about how current adaptations in animals are shaped by past functions, random events or current necessities. This research addresses this question directly, by studying a common bird species, the House Finch. Over the last century, House Finches have successfully colonized much of North America. As a result of their ongoing colonization, House Finches are now found in a wide range of habitats. They have evolved diverse, yet precise, beak shapes that enable them to thrive in new environments. Capitalizing on a unique network of long-term study populations that span diverse habitats and histories, the researchers will trace the origin of developmental mechanisms that produce such versatility. The key benefit of this work is that it allows us to decipher how a species history shapes and predicts its current adaptability and future survival. The highly visible nature of bird invasions helps ensure continuing public participation in this research. In addition, the researchers will take advantage of well-established local media contacts, and collaborations with a range of tribal, rural, and naturalist groups to engage public audiences. 

For evolution to proceed, maintaining currently adaptive traits must not prevent innovation in the same traits. Although such a system must be in place for traits to evolve, its organizational principles are largely unknown. In this project, the researchers focus on a natural system where it is possible to directly observe how the past influences the development of new adaptations. As House Finch populations have expanded across North America, they have created a network of recently established populations that differ in the amount of time each population has been established in a new environment. These populations allow the researchers to simultaneously observe how complex beak architecture evolves to different habitats as it happens. Specifically, by exploring patterns in transcription and growth factors known to regulate beak development, the researchers can gain insight into how the past influences adaptive evolution. The contrast between the patterns observed in transcription and growth factors provides crucial insight into the mechanisms behind historical continuity of past and present functional forms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Life forms combine two seemingly opposite properties: they must be resistant to change to function, yet be flexible to persist under changing conditions.  How these two properties are reconciled has long been a mystery. For example, how precise fit of bird beaks to their diet – a textbook example of evolution -- is reconciled with equally well-documented diversification of beaks when food sources change? Diversification is fueled by variation in beak development, but where does this variation hide in order not to interfere with maintenance of local precision in each environment? In other words, why each specialization is not an evolutionary dead-end? How can adaptations be both specific and flexible?  Evolution is a fundamentally historic science in which we commonly interpret past processes from their present-day outcomes. But an alternative approach, needed to answer these questions, is to design a study system where one can witness evolution in both forward and reverse directions, observing directly how adaptations evolve, how life forms transit between adaptations, and how similar adaptations evolve from different starting points. This was the approach of this long-term study. We first thoroughly documented diverse evolutionary trajectories undertaken by the world’s most successful avian colonizer and then explored developmental organization that underlies such versatility.

 From two sources – a native population in the southwest and a cageful of birds released from a pet store in New York in late 1930s, house finches had tremendously expanded their ecological and geographical range becoming in the process one of the most widespread and numerous North American songbirds. Both western and eastern colonizations had now met at the Continental Divide along northern Rocky Mountains Front. It is now common to find birds of widely distinct genetic heritage within a few miles of each other on the opposite sides of the Divide. In this project, we capitalized on this well-documented history of range expansion and associated genetic divergence to establish dozens of study populations on both sides of Continental Divide in Montana. These populations form stepping stones in the evolution of an array of adaptations – from distinct beak morphologies needed to extract different seeds in novel habitats to physiological changes needed to maintain species-specific coloration despite distinct dietary pigments.

 

In addition to the main goal of the project -- discovering mechanisms that enable these birds to adapt to such a diverse array of environment— we also sought to develop a set of novel molecular and developmental resources to be used by researchers who study non-model organisms in the wild. We fulfilled this goal by publishing dozens of open-access protocols for histological and biochemical assays of protein expression central to avian beak specification, created and distributed an open-source free software that enables simultaneous assessment of cellular morphology and protein expression at multiple levels of biological organization across millions of samples, created comprehensive atlas of histological transformations for development of avian beak, and re-sequenced two dozens of genomes across newly established populations to perfect the technique of assessing structural organization of key signaling proteins and documenting population-level variability in these proteins.

 Using an array of techniques ranging from ecological observations to biophysical reconstructions of molecular mechanisms to detailed histological assays, we pinpointed sources of molecular and developmental organization underlying remarkable versatility of beak morphology in our study species. Among main discoveries of the project is 1) demonstration that the rules governing cell behavior in early development are mirrored in the patterns of population divergence, 2) finding that the structure of gene regulatory networks delineates directions of evolutionary change, 3) discovery of the structural principles of enzymatic network organization that assure consistent plumage pigmentation across populations despite wide divergence in dietary precursors. 

 

Capitalizing on this study system and developed methodology, teams of undergraduate students also investigated pathogen transmission in relation to social network, evolutionary divergence of song architecture, and the evolution of eggshell permeability.   In addition to publishing these findings, resources, and data, we have trained five graduate students, more than 30 undergraduate students, high school students and research assistants and four postdoctoral fellows.

Our research group presented advances generated by this long-term project at more than 50 presentations at venues ranging from international congresses to local schools to teacher training workshops.
